review_title: This is a wonderful place to work. Most of the faculty and staff are dedicated to their work.
pros: A lot of freedom to job craft and have fantastic supervisors. This is a place where your hard work is rewarded.
cons: The salary is lower than most colleges, however is comparable to the cost of living in the rural areas of Western NY.

pros: Small community of some lovely people
cons: New administration moving towards hyper politically conservative values. You may think you can quietly hold a different belief, whether about faith, political issue, etc, but if you are found out there will be a manufactured reason for you to be fired. Post secondary institutions are generally expected to value rigorous debate and dialogue with different perspectives. That is not welcome here. The administration makes press releases and sweeping generalities in the strategic plan and press, but their actions and investments tell a different story. After a huge press buzz about commitment to carbon neutrality and environmental stewardship, the major, center for environmental sustainability and related programming (which paid for itself) was shut down. A deeply beloved 16 year staff member fired. Another example is the college supposedly values DEI - but closed the urban Buffalo campus serving primarily people of color as well as the Mosaic multicultural center, and fired a woman of color in res life for using pronouns in her email signature. In addition to all that hypocrisy, you will be overworked and underpaid. The last raise for faculty and staff was 3%. As the university is in the middle of nowhere, you will be extremely limited in quality of housing and access to amenities. And due to the size of the community, it is impossible to truly disconnect from work and have a vibrant personal life where you can bring your whole self, because you never know who you can truly trust or what word will make it’s way through the grapevine to the president’s office. Even if you are a right wing GOP conservatism, the atmosphere is a bait and switch- you will feel stifled here. There is no true advancement opportunities unless you accept title changes without additional compensation. There is a lot of lip service language, but not integrity. And they are running out of money fast.

pros: Good work environment. Fair amount of autonomy. Very flexible.
cons: Not full time, experience, degrees (even grad degrees in Ed) and previous salary are not considered in pay rate.

pros: This is a close-knit community that doesn't always agree with each other on politics or specific religious perspectives but everyone treats each other with respect. Everyone believes deeply in Houghton's mission and sees the value of a liberal arts grounding even in an age where it is valued less and less.
cons: Its biggest drawback will be a strength to many. It is located in the middle of woods, deer, foxes, rivers, and hills. It takes a few minutes to get a McDonald's, but that might actually be a strength.

review_title: Good working environment, not the best support
pros: The people are great, very kind and supportive. You feel like part of something.
cons: It can be easy to find yourself taken advantage of, not necessarily paid what you are worth

job_title: English Teacher in New York, NY
pros: Beautiful, peaceful place to live and work. Strong academic program.
cons: Conservative institution and community. Low population.
Can be hard to live in such a remote place.

review_title: Decent place to work but has its problems
pros: Houghton has a great community atmosphere, where faculty generally care about the students, and staff members are always going over and above. Although in a very rural area, the campus is beautiful, and most of the programs academically rigorous. It is overall an extremely safe campus, with most of the staff being very friendly.
cons: Houghton does NOT invest in its staff much at all, and they get paid significantly lower than industry averages (although the rural area has an effect on this). There is favoritism happening even with staff/faculty members who should be reprimanded, as you are 'immune' once you become a favorite of the President (even when you might be wrong or treat people unprofessionally), There is also slight nepotism with one or two Houghton area families in particular working there. Budget scarcity has become an annual thing, discouraging many employees.

review_title: Looking to leave due to enrollment decline and severe financial stress
pros: Houghton is a safe place to raise a family.  It is a quiet community that is close to letchworth state park.  The community is very small.
cons: Poor compensation.  No retirement benefits.  Poor/expensive healthcare coverage.  Declining enrollment.  Frequent layoffs.  Significant budget shortfalls.  Poor institutional health.  Nearest major grocery store/hospital is 45 minutes away.

review_title: Disappointed. Struggling with enrollment and continual layoffs/forced retirements
pros: Others have mentioned a family-like atmosphere and to an extent, that's very true. This is a small college in a tiny town and everyone knows everybody else, for good or ill. Most of the people working here are a pleasure to work with and are genuinely friendly. Some of the folks here were at my wedding and helped me move my stuff when my family relocated here.
cons:
1. There have been continual layoffs and forced retirements for a number of years now (at least 6 years in a row). This has prompted what can sometimes be a dismal environment or at least a perpetual source of anxiety. The school relies heavily on enrollment to make their budgetary goals which makes their ever-shrinking student population that much more distressing and depressing. We were told in my department that if we weren't comfortable with how the latest round of eliminations of programs and staff would come across to prospective students, then we should seriously reconsider why we were working there in the first place. On the one hand I understand the need to put our best foot forward and hope for the best. But there was no outlet for all the frustration and it was incredibly arrogant to effectively tell us to just ‘deal with it’ as more of our friends and colleagues were being forced out.
2. The school's money woes have led to a loss of staff and/or the ability to retain top talent. This means that everyone is doing the jobs of multiple others and it’s just... expected that you should be ok with this.
3. Pay and benefits were below mediocre. No dental, little professional development, and work life balance was frequently poor. I was told in my interview that overtime would be optional depending on my schedule, but it quickly became apparent that I would be asked to spend lots of evenings working only when I didn't volunteer to do this myself in the first place.
4. Nearly everyone on staff who works there has graduated from the school. On the one hand, this contributes to a sense of community and ownership. On the other, it's no wonder that only those who have a strong sense of nostalgia are willing to endure working here for long periods of time.
5. We worked head over heels to try and convince prospective students that this remote location in western, NY was worth their while because of the natural beauty of the area and how vibrant campus life would be. But in the end... especially from a staff member's point of view, there is very little going on in this area and in the surrounding towns. Most anything of interest is an hour and a half away in any direction. It makes working at Houghton feel incredibly remote. Not great for single people especially!
6. I felt very uncomfortable with how the school set up intentionally low boundaries regarding job responsibilities and my personal life. I don’t want the ability nor to be routinely encouraged to donate to the school through payroll deductions.

review_title: After years of work, decided to cut my loses and leave
cons:
Poor management
Severe budget cuts
Multiple faculty and staff cuts
Outrageous insurance costs
Retirement is non-existant

pros: The staff here support each other and the students. There is a community of support and in general faculty believe in the work they're doing.
cons: It's in the middle of nowhere. Some might consider that a pro. The pay isn't as good as some other institutions.

pros: Good people, friendly envrionment, and a satifying place to work. I really can't complain about the workload or much else.
cons: It's kind of low pay, and there isn't really much else benefits wise. Other than that, a good place.

review_title: Assistant Professor of Violin and Viola
job_title: Instructor of Violin and Viola in Rochester, NY
pros: The students and the faculty are all working together to be members of a team.
cons: I have nothing negative to say about Houghton College.  It was a truly pleasant experience.

pros: Plenty of opportunities for Communication majors. Managers and such are friendly and respectable.
cons: They are too nice and it is almost sickening. This one time at band camp.

pros: Great to get to know professors one on one, and get good experience under your belt.
cons: Minimum wage and only 10 hours per week.

pros: Great atmosphere to be a part of
This was once a marvelous institution with a great history but it has fallen on hard times and has serious enrollment and financial problems.
cons: Low enrollment, poor location, financial problems, low employee morale, frequent lay-offs

pros: Great helping staff to work with.
